elements.content: Two novel nickel coordination polymers [Ni2(2,2‘-bipy)2(OH)2(H2btec)]3 n (1) and [Ni2(1,10‘-phen)2(H2O)2(btec)] n (2) (btec = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate) have been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by elemental analyses, IR and XPS spectra, TG analysis, X-ray powder diffraction, and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Crystal data for 1:  C90H66N12O30Ni6, monoclinic P21/c, a = 10.905(2) Å, b = 18.006(4) Å, c = 20.551(4) Å, β = 94.91(3)°, Z = 2. Crystal data for 2:  C34H22N4O10Ni2, monoclinic P21/n, a = 10.122(2) Å, b = 9.3106(19) Å, c = 15.690(3) Å, β = 92.03(3)°, Z = 2. Compound 1 exhibits a novel one-dimensional chainlike structure, in which the dinuclear Ni centers are linked by the btec ligands. Furthermore, the adjacent chains are linked into a 2-D wavelike layer via the strong OH···O hydrogen bonding interactions. Compound 2 possesses an unusual two-dimensional steplike network with interesting rhombic grids. Both compounds exhibit unprecedented metal−organic ligand construction modes in {M/btec/L} (M = transition metal; L = chelate ligands) systems. The magnetic behaviors of compounds 1 and 2 have been studied.

The magnetic behaviors of compounds 1 and 2 have been studied.

elements.content:
Two novel nickel coordination polymers with 2-D gridlike networks are constructed by mixed 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate and chelate ligands.

Low dimensional coordination polymers, generally including one-dimensional (1-D) chainlike and two-dimensional (2-D) layerlike structures, have received much attention in recent years owing to their intriguing structural features and unique electroconductive, nonlinear optic, and magnetic properties different from those of three-dimensional (3-D) coordination polymers. To date, a great variety of low dimensional coordination polymers based on d-block transition metal ions and organic ligands have been prepared and exhibit potential applications in the field of functional materials. Organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligands, as one of multidentate O-donor ligands, have been extensively employed in the preparation of such coordination polymers with multidimensional networks. In this respect, 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate (btec) has attracted great interest owing to its two interesting structural features. In the first place, it contains multiple bridging moieties, which leads to a variety of connection modes with transition metal centers and provides abundant structural motifs. In the second place, it can act not only as hydrogen bond donors but also as acceptors due to the existence of protonated and/or deprotonated carboxyl groups. Therefore, the btec ligand is regarded as an excellent candidate for the construction of multidimensional coordination polymers, especially 3-D open frameworks. However, the introduction of another kind of N-donor chelate ligand such as 2,2‘-bipy or 1,10‘-phen in the {M/btec} (M = transitional metal) system may induce new structural evolution. It is well-known that the chelate ligands are capable of “passivating” metal sites via the N donors of the organic groups. Thus, the introduction of N-donor chelate ligands into the metal sites may inhibit the expansion of the polymeric frameworks and obtain the desired low dimensional coordination polymers. However, the syntheses of compounds containing mixed ligands are expected to be more difficult to control than those of compounds containing only one ligand. This is due to several reasons, such as the different solubility of mixed organic ligands and the coordination competition of mixed organic ligands with transition metal centers. Until now, the coordination polymers constructed from the mixed btec and N-containing chelate ligands have rarely been reported. Recent plentiful practice has proved that hydrothermal synthesis is a powerful method for the construction of such organic−inorganic hybrid materials. In such a relatively low temperature and autogenous pressure environment, problems of different solubility for various ligands are minimized, and appropriate O-donor and N-donor ligands may be selected by the metal centers for efficient molecular building during the crystallization process.

elements.content: On the basis of the aforementioned points, we have attempted to study the hydrothermal synthesis and magnetic properties of low dimensional d-block transition metal coordination polymers with mixed btec and bidentate chelate ligands. In this paper, we report two new nickel coordination polymers [Ni2(2,2‘-bipy)2(OH)2(H2btec)]3 n (1) and [Ni2(1,10‘-phen)2(H2O)2(btec)] n (2). Compound 1 exhibits a novel 1-D chainlike structure, in which the dinuclear Ni centers are connected by the btec ligands. Furthermore, the adjacent chains are linked into a 2-D wavelike layer via the strong hydrogen bonding interactions between the OH and COOH groups. Compound 2 possesses an interesting 2-D steplike network with unusual rhombic grids. To our knowledge, both compounds exhibit unprecedented connection modes in the {M/btec/L} (M = transition metal; L = chelate ligands) system. The variable temperature magnetic susceptibilities of compounds 1 and 2 were studied.

elements.content: General Methods. All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. Ni was determined by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. XPS analysis was performed on a VG ESCALAB MK II spectrometer with a Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) achromatic X-ray source. The vacuum inside the analysis chamber was maintained at 6.2 × 10-6 Pa during analysis. FTIR spectra were recorded in the range 400−4000 cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FTIR spectrophotometer using a KBr pellet. TG-DTA analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were recorded on a Siemens D5005 diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility was measured at 5000 Oe from 2 to 300 K (SQUID, Quantum Design).

Experimental Section

 General Methods. All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. Ni was determined by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. XPS analysis was performed on a VG ESCALAB MK II spectrometer with a Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) achromatic X-ray source. The vacuum inside the analysis chamber was maintained at 6.2 × 10-6 Pa during analysis. FTIR spectra were recorded in the range 400-4000 cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FTIR spectrophotometer using a KBr pellet. TG-DTA analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were recorded on a Siemens D5005 diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility was measured at 5000 Oe from 2 to 300 K (SQUID, Quantum Design).

elements.content: Hydrothermal Syntheses. [Ni 2 (2,2‘-bipy) 2 (OH) 2 (H 2 btec)] 3 n (1). Compound 1 was synthesized from the reaction mixture of Ni(OAc)2·4H2O (0.5 mmol), 2,2‘-bipy (0.5 mmol), H4btec (0.5 mmol), NaOH (1 mmol), and H2O (8 mL) in an 18 mL Teflon-lined autoclave under autogenous pressure at 160 °C for 5 days, followed by slow cooling (5 °C/h) to room temperature. The initial pH value of the solution was kept in the range ∼5−6, and the final pH value was ca. 6.8. Green block crystals were obtained with amorphous powder. The crystals were picked out, washed with distilled water, and air-dried at 50 °C (yield:  50% based on Ni). Elemental Anal. Found:  C, 50.6; H, 3.4; N, 8.1; Ni 16.0%. Calcd for C90H66N12O30Ni6:  C, 50.3; H, 3.1; N, 7.8; Ni, 16.4%. Selected FTIR data (cm-1):  1606(w), 1579(m), 1561(s), 1490(s), 1470(s), 1440(s), 1427(m), 1390(s), 1315(s), 1249(m), 1164(w), 1136(m), 1116(w), 1056(s), 1029(s), 951(w), 872(w), 863(m), 814(m), 802(m), 765(s), 735(s), 656(s), 636(m), 594(m), 549(s), 454(s), 416(s).

elements.content: [Ni 2 (1,10‘-phen) 2 (H 2 O) 2 (btec)] n (2). Compound 2 was synthesized from the reaction mixture of Ni(OAc)2·4H2O (0.5 mmol), 1,10‘-phen (0.5 mmol), H4btec (0.5 mmol), NaOH (2 mmol), and H2O (8 mL) in an 18 mL Teflon-lined autoclave under autogenous pressure at 140 °C for 2 days, followed by slow cooling (10 °C/h) to room temperature. The pH value of the reactive solution was ca. 8.5 and the final pH value was ca. 9. The product was filtered, washed with distilled water and air-dried at 50 °C. The product was of high quality in the form of blue block crystals (yield:  90% based on Ni). Elemental Anal. Found:  C, 53.8; H, 3.2; N, 7.6; Ni 14.9%. Calcd for C34H22N4O10Ni2:  C, 53.4; H, 2.9; N, 7.3; Ni, 15.4%. elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Single crystals of 1 and 2 with dimensions 0.43 × 0.38 × 0.21 mm3 and 0.43 × 0.38 × 0.21 mm3, respectively, were glued on a glass fiber. Data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer with Mo Kα monochromated radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Empirical absorption correction was applied. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 using the SHELXTL crystallographic software package. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps. The crystal data and structure refinement of compounds 1 and 2 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles of compounds 1 and 2 are listed in Table .

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures. [Ni 2 (2,2‘-bipy) 2 (OH) 2 (H 2 btec)] 3 n (1). X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that 1 is a 1-D chainlike polymer. The fundamental unit is shown in Figure a. There are two Ni centers in the 1-D chain. Each Ni site coordinates to two nitrogen atoms of one 2,2‘-bipy group, two carboxyl oxygen atoms of different btec ligands, and two bridging oxygen atoms of the sharing hydroxyl groups. The average Ni−N bond length is 2.062 Å, and the Ni−O(carboxyl groups) bond lengths are in the range ∼2.084(2)−2.142(2) Å, while the Ni−O(hydroxyl group) bond lengths vary from 2.028(2) to 2.066(3) Å. The N(O)−Ni−O(N) bond angles range from 78.44(12)° to 162.81(10)° (see Table ). Thus, both Ni2+ centers display distorted octahedral coordination geometry, and two octahedra are connected together via an edge-sharing mode. The four carboxyl groups of the btec ligand exhibit two kinds of coordination modes as shown in Scheme a. That is, two of them adopt a monodentate bridging mode to connect with two Ni centers, while the other two act as the hydrogen bond acceptors to link with the adjacent chains. On the basis of this connection mode, all dinuclear Ni clusters are linked by two bridging btec ligands to form a 1-D chain along the a axis (see Figure b). In contrast to the reported compounds in the {M/btec/L} (M= transition metal ions, L = N-donor chelate ligands) system, compound 1 represents the first dinuclear compound connected by the mixed ligands. Furthermore, the adjacent chains are connected together through hydrogen bonding interactions between the two noncoordinated carboxyl groups of btec ligands and the OH groups on the dinuclear clusters. The typical hydrogen bonds are O(1A)···O(8B) 2.550 Å, O(2A)···O(14B) 2.591 Å, and O(11A)···O(6B) 2.560 Å (see Table ). Thus, a 2-D square gridlike supramolecular network is formed via both coordinating and hydrogen bonding interactions (see Figure b). It is also noteworthy that there exist two kinds of crystallographic unique chains in the crystal structure, which possess different rolling angles along the a axis and adopt an AABAA arrangement in the supramolecular network as shown in Figure S1. Therefore, the 2-D supramolecular network exhibits a wavelike layer.

elements.content: In the packing arrangement of 1 (Figure S2), the adjacent 2-D wavelike supramolecular layers are parallel with each other and construct a 3-D framework via the π−π interactions between aromatic groups of 2,2‘-bipy. The average distance of the aromatic units (2,2‘-bipy) is about 3.45 Å. The hydrogen bonds and π−π interactions enhance the stability of the compound.

elements.content: Valence sum calculations give the average value of 1.9 for all Ni atoms, suggesting that all Ni centers are in the +2 oxidation state. This result is also proved by XPS measurement of compound 1 in the energy region of Ni2p1/2 and Ni2p3/2. The XPS spectrum (see Figure S4) gives one peak at 855.3 eV, attributable to Ni2+. The uncoordinated oxygen atoms O(6) and O(8) of the btec ligands and the bridging oxygen atoms O(1) and O(2) have bond valence sums of 1.3, 1.3, 0.7, and 0.6, respectively. These values suggest that O(6) and O(8) are protonated carboxyl oxygen atoms, while O(1) and O(2) are hydroxyl groups. These results are consistent with the charge balance considerations and slightly acidic synthetic conditions of compound 1.

elements.content: [Ni 2 (1,10‘-phen) 2 (H 2 O) 2 (btec)] n (2). X-ray crystallographic analysis shows that compound 2 exhibits an interesting 2-D network. The fundamental unit of compound 2 is shown in Figure a. There is only one crystallographically unique Ni center in the crystal structure. The Ni center coordinates to two nitrogen atoms of one 1,10‘-phen group, three oxygen atoms of two different carboxylate groups, and one oxygen atom of a water molecule. The Ni−N bond lengths vary from 2.061(4) to 2.083(4) Å, and the Ni−O(carboxyl) bond lengths are in the range ∼2.050(3)−2.136(4) Å, while the Ni−OW bond length is 2.052(3) Å. The O(N)−Ni−N(O) bond angles range from 80.62(15)° to 175.35(15)°. Therefore, all Ni centers display distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Unlike those in compound 1, the four carboxyl groups of the btec ligand in compound 2 exhibit another kind of coordination mode with the Ni atoms, as shown in Scheme b. That is, two of the carboxyl groups adopt a bidentate chelating mode, while the other two exhibit a monodentate bridging mode. The most interesting structural feature of 2 is that it exhibits a novel 2-D network with unusual rhombic grids, which so far have not been observed in the {M/btec/L} (M = transition metal; L = chelate ligands) system. The rhombic grid possesses an eight-membered ring composed of four btec ligands and four Ni octahedra (see Figure (b)). The size of these rhombic grids is ca. 12.00 × 9.47 Å2 (see Table ). It is also noteworthy that the 2-D network of 2 is not a smooth plane but essentially a steplike layer as shown in Figure S3. In the packing arrangement of 2, the adjacent 2-D steplike layers are parallel with each other and construct a 3-D framework via the π−π interactions between aromatic groups of 1,10‘-phen ligands, which project perpendicularly beyond the layer. The narrowest interplanar distance of the aromatic units is ca. 3.41 Å. The π−π interactions enhance the stability of the compound and lead to a higher dimensional structure with interesting 1-D quadrangle tunnels parallel with each other along the a axis (see Figure S3). The tunnel size is about 4.0 × 7.8 Å2. Because no extra guest H2O molecules exist in the structure, the whole compound exhibits an interesting hollow host scaffolding.

elements.content: IR Spectra and XRPD and TG-DTA Analyses. The IR spectrum of compound 1 is shown in Figure S5a. The main IR absorption peaks of 1 are listed in Table S1. The strong peaks at 1470 and 1440 cm-1 indicate the existence of pronated carboxylic groups in compound 1. Furthermore, the value of Δν (62 cm-1) for 1 is smaller than the corresponding value for Na4btec (95 cm-1), indicating that the carboxylate groups coordinate to the metal atoms in a bidentate fashion. The IR spectrum of 2 is shown in Figure S5b and Table S1. The absence of strong peaks around 1470 and 1440 cm-1 indicates that all carboxylic groups are depronated in compound 2. The values of Δν for 2 show that the carboxylate groups coordinate to the metal atoms in both monodentate (167 cm-1) and bidentate (62 cm-1) fashions.

elements.content: The TG curve of 1 exhibits two continuous weight loss stages in the temperature ranges 220−280 and 300−500 °C (see Figure S7a), corresponding to the concomitant release of composed water and 2,2‘-bipy and btec groups. The residue was NiO. The whole weight loss (79.14%) is in good agreement with the calculated value (79.29%). Three endothermic peaks (285, 344, and 437°C) in the DTA curve also record the weight loss processes of various groups. The thermogravimetric analysis indicates that compound 2 has good stability. The TG curve exhibits that there is no weight loss from room temperature to 220 °C (see Figure S7b). The first weight loss is 5.1% in the temperature range 227−260 °C, the second weight loss is 47.3% in the range of 265−320 °C, and the third weight loss is 27.9% from 325 to 400 °C, corresponding to the release of coordinated water and 1,10‘-phen and btec ligands, respectively. The residue is NiO. The whole weight loss (80.3%) is in good agreement with the calculated value (80.4%). The DTA curve also confirms that the network of compound 2 is stable below 220 °C.

elements.content: Magnetic Properties. The thermal variations of χm, χm T, and 1/χ of compound 1 are displayed in Figure a. The χm T versus T exhibits a value of 10.86 emu K Oe-1 mol-1 at 300 K and continuously increases on cooling to a value of 14.05 emu K Oe-1 mol-1 at 7 K. This behavior of the χm T curve shows that there exist ferromagnetic interactions in 1. However, the curve drops abruptly below 4 K, indicating that an antiferromagnetic interaction exists in 1 at lower temperatures. The inverse susceptibility plot as a function of temperature is linear (above 4 K), closely following the Curie−Weiss law with C = 10.92 emu K Oe-1 mol-1, corresponding to about one S = 1 spin per formula unit with g = 2.09 for Ni(II) centers. The effective magnetic moment per metal atom at 300 K, 2.95 μB, is in the range of experimentally observed values for Ni(II) ions. The Weiss temperature θ = 3.52 K, indicating that there exist predominantly ferromagnetic interactions between metallic Ni(II) centers. According to the crystal structure of 1, it can be assumed that the magnetic behavior of 1 may be due to the existence of Ni−O−Ni connectivity and Ni−Ni (2.91 Å) interactions.

elements.content: The magnetic behavior of compound 2 is shown in Figure b. The plot of χm T versus T shows a value of 12.08 emu K Oe-1 mol-1 at 300 K and almost no changes on cooling to a value of 12.04 emu K Oe-1 mol-1 at 14 K. From 14 to 2 K, the curve drops abruptly to a value of 1.64 emu K Oe-1 mol-1. This behavior of the χm T curve shows that there exist antiferromagnetic interactions among metal Ni(II) centers. In the χm T curve, a small increase of the magnetic susceptibility is observed below 7 K. It is assumed that the existence of a very small amount of the paramagnetic impurity leads to the Curie behavior in this temperature region. The inverse susceptibility plot as a function of temperature is linear above 9 K, following the Curie−Weiss law with C = 12.24 emu K Oe-1 mol-1, corresponding to about one S = 1 spin per formula unit with g = 2.21 for Ni(II) centers. The effective magnetic moment per metal atom at 300 K, 3.13 μB, is in the range of experimentally observed values for high spin Ni(II) ions. The Weiss temperature, θ = −1.23 K, indicates that there exist predominantly antiferromagnetic interactions between metallic Ni(II) centers. The magnetic behavior of compound 2 is different from those of related Ni(II) coordination polymers containing carboxylate ligands. According to the structure of compound 2, it could be presumed that the superexchange interactions between Ni(II) ions through the btec bridge are very weak, which may lead to such a magnetic behavior.

elements.content: In this paper, the successful syntheses of 1-D and 2-D nickel coordination polymers of 1 and 2 not only prove the strong capability of hydrothermal reactions in preparing novel organic−inorganic hybrid materials with mixed organic ligands but also further confirm that such coordination polymers may be designed and synthesized according to the inherent stereo and interactive information stored in the organic ligands and metal ions. The extended research on the structural chemistry of this system may focus on the replacement of nickel and 2,2‘-bipy and/or phen with other transition metals and multidentate chelate ligands. Further research is going on to prepare novel polymeric frameworks in this subfield and explore their valuable properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this paper, the successful syntheses of 1-D and 2-D nickel coordination polymers of 1 and 2 not only prove the strong capability of hydrothermal reactions in preparing novel organic-inorganic hybrid materials with mixed organic ligands but also further confirm that such coordination polymers may be designed and synthesized according to the inherent stereo and interactive information stored in the organic ligands and metal ions. The extended research on the structural chemistry of this system may focus on the replacement of nickel and 2,2‘-bipy and/or phen with other transition metals and multidentate chelate ligands. Further research is going on to prepare novel polymeric frameworks in this subfield and explore their valuable properties.

cln_elements.content:
Hydrothermal Syntheses. [Ni 2 (2,2‘-bipy) 2 (OH) 2 (H 2 btec)] 3 n (1). Compound 1 was synthesized from the reaction mixture of Ni(OAc)2·4H2O (0.5 mmol), 2,2‘-bipy (0.5 mmol), H4btec (0.5 mmol), NaOH (1 mmol), and H2O (8 mL) in an 18 mL Teflon-lined autoclave under autogenous pressure at 160 °C for 5 days, followed by slow cooling (5 °C/h) to room temperature. The initial pH value of the solution was kept in the range ∼5−6, and the final pH value was ca. 6.8. Green block crystals were obtained with amorphous powder. The crystals were picked out, washed with distilled water, and air-dried at 50 °C (yield:  50% based on Ni). Elemental Anal. Found:  C, 50.6; H, 3.4; N, 8.1; Ni 16.0%. Calcd for C90H66N12O30Ni6:  C, 50.3; H, 3.1; N, 7.8; Ni, 16.4%. Selected FTIR data (cm-1):  1606(w), 1579(m), 1561(s), 1490(s), 1470(s), 1440(s), 1427(m), 1390(s), 1315(s), 1249(m), 1164(w), 1136(m), 1116(w), 1056(s), 1029(s), 951(w), 872(w), 863(m), 814(m), 802(m), 765(s), 735(s), 656(s), 636(m), 594(m), 549(s), 454(s), 416(s).

[Ni 2 (1,10‘-phen) 2 (H 2 O) 2 (btec)] n (2). Compound 2 was synthesized from the reaction mixture of Ni(OAc)2·4H2O (0.5 mmol), 1,10‘-phen (0.5 mmol), H4btec (0.5 mmol), NaOH (2 mmol), and H2O (8 mL) in an 18 mL Teflon-lined autoclave under autogenous pressure at 140 °C for 2 days, followed by slow cooling (10 °C/h) to room temperature. The pH value of the reactive solution was ca. 8.5 and the final pH value was ca. 9. The product was filtered, washed with distilled water and air-dried at 50 °C. The product was of high quality in the form of blue block crystals (yield:  90% based on Ni). Elemental Anal. Found:  C, 53.8; H, 3.2; N, 7.6; Ni 14.9%. Calcd for C34H22N4O10Ni2:  C, 53.4; H, 2.9; N, 7.3; Ni, 15.4%. Selected FTIR data (cm-1):  1624(w), 1585(s), 1547(s), 1516(s), 1490(s), 1428(s), 1380(s), 1324(s), 1288(w), 1226(w), 1154(w), 1141(s), 1107(m), 1005(w), 961(w), 921(s), 868(m), 854(s), 815(s), 779(s), 770(w), 727(s), 681(s), 646(m), 568(s), 536(s), 465(s), 428(s).

The TG curve of 1 exhibits two continuous weight loss stages in the temperature ranges 220-280 and 300-500 °C (see Figure S7a), corresponding to the concomitant release of composed water and 2,2‘-bipy and btec groups. The residue was NiO. The whole weight loss (79.14%) is in good agreement with the calculated value (79.29%). Three endothermic peaks (285, 344, and 437°C) in the DTA curve also record the weight loss processes of various groups. The thermogravimetric analysis indicates that compound 2 has good stability. The TG curve exhibits that there is no weight loss from room temperature to 220 °C (see Figure S7b). The first weight loss is 5.1% in the temperature range 227-260 °C, the second weight loss is 47.3% in the range of 265-320 °C, and the third weight loss is 27.9% from 325 to 400 °C, corresponding to the release of coordinated water and 1,10‘-phen and btec ligands, respectively. The residue is NiO. The whole weight loss (80.3%) is in good agreement with the calculated value (80.4%). The DTA curve also confirms that the network of compound 2 is stable below 220 °C. 

 Magnetic Properties. The thermal variations of χm, χm T, and 1/χ of compound 1 are displayed in Figure a. The χm T versus T exhibits a value of 10.86 emu K Oe-1 mol-1 at 300 K and continuously increases on cooling to a value of 14.05 emu K Oe-1 mol-1 at 7 K. This behavior of the χm T curve shows that there exist ferromagnetic interactions in 1.  However, the curve drops abruptly below 4 K, indicating that an antiferromagnetic interaction exists in 1 at lower temperatures. The inverse susceptibility plot as a function of temperature is linear (above 4 K), closely following the Curie-Weiss law with C = 10.92 emu K Oe-1 mol-1, corresponding to about one S = 1 spin per formula unit with g = 2.09 for Ni(II) centers. The effective magnetic moment per metal atom at 300 K, 2.95 μB, is in the range of experimentally observed values for Ni(II) ions. The Weiss temperature θ = 3.52 K, indicating that there exist predominantly ferromagnetic interactions between metallic Ni(II) centers. According to the crystal structure of 1, it can be assumed that the magnetic behavior of 1 may be due to the existence of Ni-O-Ni connectivity and Ni-Ni (2.91 Å) interactions.
